title: Chinese Government provides grant for Rural School Construction Project
description: At the Beijing Summit of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation, the Chinese government put forward eight measures to assist Africa, including the construction of 100 rural schools for African countries. At the request of the Republic of Guinea-Bissau, the Chinese Government agreed to build two rural schools for Guinea-Bissau. Then, in October 2007, the two governments signed an exchange of letters regarding the Rural School Construction Project. The monetary value of the grant from China’s Ministry of Commerce that supported this project is unknown. The project was originally designed to support the construction of two schools in the provinces of Cacheu and Bafatá.  Each school — with a construction area of ​​approximately 1,100 square meters — would be able to accommodate 300 children. However, MOFCOM ultimately support the construction of a third school it the city of Bissau. China Henan International Cooperation Group Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project design and implementation, and China Youfa International Engineering Design and Consulting Company was responsible for the construction supervision. Construction began in May 2008 and ended in January 2009.
staff_comments: The Portuguese project title is Escolas de Amizade Sino-Guineense. The Chinese project title is 中几比友谊小学 or 中几比友谊小学巴法塔、比绍、卡谢乌校区.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant for Rural School Construction Project

# Description
At the Beijing Summit of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation, the Chinese government put forward eight measures to assist Africa, including the construction of 100 rural schools for African countries. At the request of the Republic of Guinea-Bissau, the Chinese Government agreed to build two rural schools for Guinea-Bissau. Then, in October 2007, the two governments signed an exchange of letters regarding the Rural School Construction Project. The monetary value of the grant from China’s Ministry of Commerce that supported this project is unknown. The project was originally designed to support the construction of two schools in the provinces of Cacheu and Bafatá.  Each school — with a construction area of ​​approximately 1,100 square meters — would be able to accommodate 300 children. However, MOFCOM ultimately support the construction of a third school it the city of Bissau. China Henan International Cooperation Group Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project design and implementation, and China Youfa International Engineering Design and Consulting Company was responsible for the construction supervision. Construction began in May 2008 and ended in January 2009.
justification: Project focuses on education infrastructure without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of rural schools, education sector focus, no energy-related components mentioned

title: China provides food aid donation to Guinea-Bissau in 2007
description: On September 13, 2007, China provided a donation of food aid for Guinea-Bissau. The project was completed on September 13, 2007 when the handover of the donation was held in Bissau. The value of this project is unknown.

evidence: Food aid donation, social development focus

title: China donates rice to Guinea-Bassau
description: China donated 2,000 tons of rice to Guinea-Bassau, which allowed the regime to address the most basic immediate needs of the population while buying vital time for further shipments to arrive. This Chinese gesture may have prevented serious civil unrest, and it certainly enhanced China’s image in the eyes of the government and people. In August 2007, this first rice shipment was followed by an even larger one of 30,000 tons.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
China donates rice to Guinea-Bassau

# Description
China donated 2,000 tons of rice to Guinea-Bassau, which allowed the regime to address the most basic immediate needs of the population while buying vital time for further shipments to arrive. This Chinese gesture may have prevented serious civil unrest, and it certainly enhanced China’s image in the eyes of the government and people. In August 2007, this first rice shipment was followed by an even larger one of 30,000 tons.
justification: Food aid project with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Rice donation for food security, humanitarian assistance focus

title: Chinese Government cancels 107 million RMB of the Government of Guyana’s outstanding obligations (Linked to Project ID#36669, #92405)
description: On July 10, 2007, the Chinese Government and the Government of Guyana signed letters of exchange. Under the terms of the agreement, the Chinese Government agreed to provide RMB 107,206,063.43 (captured via Project ID#56154) and 610,000 pounds sterling of debt forgiveness (captured via Project ID#92405) to the Government of Guyana. The total USD value of this debt forgiveness action was $15.3 million, which brought the total amount of debt forgiveness provided by the Chinese Government to the Government of Guyana to approximately $34.9 million.
staff_comments: 1. The loans forgiven through this action were almost certainly interest-free loans committed through previous ETCAs. As such, the loans likely had maturity lengths of 20 years and since they had reached maturity no later than 2007, they were almost certainly contracted prior to 2000. Therefore, AidData has not assigned this record to the umbrella category (as there is little risk of double counting the monetary value of the debts that were forgiven). 2. The Chinese Government provided $20 million of additional debt forgiveness in 2003 (as captured via Project ID#36669). 3. The July 10, 2007 debt forgiveness agreement can be accessed in its entirety via https://www.dropbox.com/s/s5t4nhd9ewy2elt/
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
Chinese Government cancels 107 million RMB of the Government of Guyana’s outstanding obligations (Linked to Project ID#36669, #92405)

# Description
On July 10, 2007, the Chinese Government and the Government of Guyana signed letters of exchange. Under the terms of the agreement, the Chinese Government agreed to provide RMB 107,206,063.43 (captured via Project ID#56154) and 610,000 pounds sterling of debt forgiveness (captured via Project ID#92405) to the Government of Guyana. The total USD value of this debt forgiveness action was $15.3 million, which brought the total amount of debt forgiveness provided by the Chinese Government to the Government of Guyana to approximately $34.9 million.
justification: Debt forgiveness action with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Debt cancellation of RMB 107 million and 610,000 pounds sterling, no specific project details provided

title: China and Guyana Sign Youth Volunteer Program Agreement
description: On May 30, 2007, a team of youth volunteers left for Guyana for a one year term to assist with medical, agricultural technology, and physical education aid projects. This agreement has been renewed on several occasions, with recorded instances of Chinese youth volunteer teams in 2007, 2010, and 2012. The program was funded with the assistance of the Chinese Ministry of Commerce, and by the local Guyanese embassy.  The first team of youth volunteers arrived on June 1, 2007.  The 2012 team worked in fields including environmental science, agricultural technology, geological and mineral research, physical education, and website development. All teams appear to have been based out of Jiangsu.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China and Guyana Sign Youth Volunteer Program Agreement

# Description
On May 30, 2007, a team of youth volunteers left for Guyana for a one year term to assist with medical, agricultural technology, and physical education aid projects. This agreement has been renewed on several occasions, with recorded instances of Chinese youth volunteer teams in 2007, 2010, and 2012. The program was funded with the assistance of the Chinese Ministry of Commerce, and by the local Guyanese embassy.  The first team of youth volunteers arrived on June 1, 2007.  The 2012 team worked in fields including environmental science, agricultural technology, geological and mineral research, physical education, and website development. All teams appear to have been based out of Jiangsu.
justification: Project focuses on social development through youth volunteer programs in various fields, with no direct energy or environmental impact
evidence: Youth volunteer program in medical, agricultural, physical education, and environmental science fields; social development focus

title: Chinese 7th medical team to Guyana donates medical equipment worth RMB 650,000 (Linked to Project ID #89669)
description: Between May 17 and 19, 2007, Chinese and Guyanese officials attended a ceremony recognizing the 7th Chinese medical team (see Project ID #89669). At the ceremony, the Chinese Government donated medical equipment worth RMB 650,000.

title: China Geological Survey sends two geological experts to Guyana to conduct a three-year regional geochemical survey
description: On January 15, 2007, the China Geological Survey (CGS) signed a geology and mining cooperation agreement with the Guyana Geology and Mines Commission (GGMC). In the agreement, the CGS committed to sending two geological experts to conduct a three-year regional geochemical survey in Guyana. This was the first ever instance of the Chinese Government sending geological experts to Guyana. Implementation details are unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
China Geological Survey sends two geological experts to Guyana to conduct a three-year regional geochemical survey

# Description
On January 15, 2007, the China Geological Survey (CGS) signed a geology and mining cooperation agreement with the Guyana Geology and Mines Commission (GGMC). In the agreement, the CGS committed to sending two geological experts to conduct a three-year regional geochemical survey in Guyana. This was the first ever instance of the Chinese Government sending geological experts to Guyana. Implementation details are unknown.
justification: Geochemical survey without specified mineral targets or clear energy transition relevance
evidence: Regional geochemical survey, no specified mineral targets, geological cooperation agreement

title: China sends 95 peacekeeping troops to Haiti
description: On April 13, 2007, the United Nations says that more Chinese police have arrived in Haiti to aid its peacekeeping force (MINUSTAH) there. The 95 Chinese officers, including seven women, will be attached to the Formed Police Unit (FPU) in the French-speaking Caribbean country. The new officers, who joined a group of 30 FPU members of the same contingent that arrived on April 4, bring the total number of Chinese officers in Haiti to 125. The UN said, prior to their deployment to Haiti, the officers underwent a five-month training course, covering language, shooting, driving, and combat/defensive tactics. They were the fifth team of Chinese peacekeeping troops in Haiti. They had conducted their mission in Portan-Prince for 8 months and came back to China on December 15, 2007.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China sends 95 peacekeeping troops to Haiti

# Description
On April 13, 2007, the United Nations says that more Chinese police have arrived in Haiti to aid its peacekeeping force (MINUSTAH) there. The 95 Chinese officers, including seven women, will be attached to the Formed Police Unit (FPU) in the French-speaking Caribbean country. The new officers, who joined a group of 30 FPU members of the same contingent that arrived on April 4, bring the total number of Chinese officers in Haiti to 125. The UN said, prior to their deployment to Haiti, the officers underwent a five-month training course, covering language, shooting, driving, and combat/defensive tactics. They were the fifth team of Chinese peacekeeping troops in Haiti. They had conducted their mission in Portan-Prince for 8 months and came back to China on December 15, 2007.
justification: Project involves peacekeeping and security operations without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Deployment of peacekeeping troops, focus on security and stability operations
